1.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
used very widely as demonstrative, lo!; interrogative, whether?; or conditional, if, although; also Oh that!, when; hence, as a negative, not
to braid, i.e. intermix; technically, to traffic (as if by barter); also or give to be security (as a kind of exchange)
to clatter, i.e. slap (the hands together), clang (an instrument); by analogy, to drive (a nail or tent-pin, a dart, etc.); by implication, to become bondsman by handclasping)
to turn aside (especially for lodging); hence to be aforeigner, strange, profane; specifically (active participle) to commit adultery
the hollow hand or palm (so of the paw of an animal, of the sole, and even of the bowl of a dish or sling, the handle of a bolt, the leaves of a palm-tree); figuratively, power

to urge severely, i.e. (figuratively) importune, embolden, capture, act insolently

to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)

an eyelash (as fluttering); figuratively, morning ray

splendor (as conspicuous); also a gazelle (as beautiful)

near, with or among; often in general, to
an ant (probably from its almost bisected form)
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
to be wise (in mind, word or act)

a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
a magistrate (as deciding) or other leader
properly, a scribe, i.e. (by analogy or implication) an official superintendent or magistrate

harvest (as the crop), whether the product (grain or fruit) or the (dry) season
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)
severed, i.e. harvest (as reaped), the crop, the time, the reaper, or figuratively; also a limb (of a tree, or simply foliage)
an eatable (includ. provender, flesh and fruit)

an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
a foot (as used in walking); by implication, a step; by euphemistically the pudenda

14.brief: the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything

bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
time, especially (adverb with preposition) now, when, etc.
to send away, for, or out (in a great variety of applications)

properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
